short_definition: A transcription factor is a protein that controls how much of a gene is used to make a protein. It does this by attaching to specific sections of DNA, influencing whether the DNA instructions are read and used to create a protein.  This process helps ensure that the right amount of each protein is made at the right time in the right cells.

name: pulsars
short_definition: A pulsar is a type of star that spins incredibly fast and emits beams of light and other radiation from its poles. These beams are directed by the star's powerful magnetic field, and they appear as regular pulses to observers on Earth. Pulsars are extremely dense, made almost entirely of neutrons, and they are among the most fascinating objects in the universe.

name: quantum dots
short_definition: Quantum dots are tiny semiconductor particles, just a few nanometers in size. Their small size causes them to behave differently than larger particles, exhibiting unique optical and electronic properties due to quantum mechanics.  These properties are influenced by the confinement of electrons within the dot, leading to distinct energy levels that affect how they interact with light.

name: metamaterials
short_definition: Metamaterials are artificial materials designed to have special properties not found in nature. They are made by arranging tiny pieces of different materials, like metals and plastics, in precise repeating patterns. These patterns, rather than the materials themselves, give metamaterials the ability to control waves, like light or sound, in unusual ways.

name: neutron stars
short_definition: A neutron star is a super dense and tiny object formed when a massive star explodes as a supernova.  It's essentially the crushed core of that star, with a mass similar to the Sun but squeezed into a sphere only 10 kilometers across. This makes neutron stars incredibly dense, composed mainly of neutrons, tiny particles found within atoms.  The immense gravity of a neutron star is balanced by the pressure of these neutrons, preventing further collapse.

name: ecosystems
short_definition: An ecosystem is a community of living things, like plants and animals, interacting with their non-living surroundings, such as air, water, and soil.  These components work together through natural processes, like the movement of nutrients and energy.  Ecosystems are always changing and adapting to events, while trying to maintain a balance and keep their important parts functioning properly.

name: vaccines
short_definition: A vaccine is a special medicine that helps your body fight off diseases. It works by giving your immune system a little bit of a weakened or inactive version of the disease-causing germ, so your body learns how to recognize and fight it off if you're ever exposed to the real thing. This way, your body is prepared and can fight the disease quickly and effectively.

name: energy systems
short_definition: An energy system is a comprehensive network that encompasses every stage of energy, from its initial creation to its final use by consumers. This system includes the production, conversion, and delivery of energy, as well as the factors influencing how we use it, such as energy efficiency measures and societal habits.

name: stem cells
short_definition: Stem cells are special cells found in our bodies that have the unique ability to develop into different types of cells. They can copy themselves, making more stem cells, and they can also transform into specialized cells like muscle, bone, or nerve cells. These remarkable cells are crucial for repairing and maintaining our tissues throughout life.

name: composite materials
short_definition: A composite material is created by combining two or more different materials, like a mix of strong fibers and a lightweight resin. These materials keep their own identities, but together they form something stronger, lighter, or more durable than either material alone.

name: electric power systems
short_definition: An electric power system is a vast network that delivers electrical energy to consumers. It's made up of three main parts: generation, transmission, and distribution. Generation involves creating electricity, transmission sends it over long distances, and distribution delivers it to individual homes and businesses.

name: natural products
short_definition: A natural product is a chemical compound made by a living organism, like a plant or animal. These compounds aren't always essential for the organism's survival but can provide benefits like protection from predators or diseases. They are often very complex and have unique properties that make them interesting for scientific study.

name: biomarkers
short_definition: A biomarker is a measurable indicator found in the body that can signal a specific biological condition, such as a disease or a response to treatment. These indicators can be substances like molecules or gene expression profiles, and they are found in biological samples like blood, urine, or tissue.

name: clinical trials
short_definition: A clinical trial is a research study with human participants that tests the safety and effectiveness of new treatments, like drugs or medical devices.  These studies are carefully designed to understand how well the treatment works and if it has any side effects.  Participants are divided into groups, some receiving the treatment and others receiving a placebo or standard treatment, to compare the results.

name: supermassive black holes
short_definition: A supermassive black hole is an extremely massive object found at the center of most large galaxies. These black holes are incredibly dense, with a mass millions or billions of times greater than our Sun. Their immense gravity is so strong that even light cannot escape, creating a region known as the event horizon.

name: exoplanets
short_definition: An exoplanet is a planet that orbits a star outside our own solar system. These planets are made of similar elements to those in our solar system but can vary significantly in composition, with some being rocky, some being mostly gas, and some being water or ice dominated.

name: aquatic ecosystems
short_definition: An aquatic ecosystem is a community of living things that depend on each other and their watery surroundings. These ecosystems can be found in oceans, lakes, rivers, and even swamps. They are different from land-based ecosystems because the water is a key factor in how the plants and animals live and grow.

name: nanowires
short_definition: A nanowire is a tiny, wire-shaped structure that is incredibly thin, measuring only a few nanometers across.  Nanowires are made from a variety of materials, like metals, semiconductors, or insulators, and are much longer than they are wide.  The small size of nanowires leads to unique properties that are different from larger materials.

name: immune responses
short_definition: An immune response is how your body protects itself from harmful substances.  It involves recognizing and fighting off invaders like bacteria and viruses. The immune system has two main parts: the innate system, which acts as a first line of defense, and the adaptive system, which specifically targets and remembers threats.

name: ceramics
short_definition: A ceramic is a material made from non-metallic substances, like clay, that is shaped and then fired at high temperatures. These materials are known for their hardness, resistance to heat, and resistance to corrosion.

name: management information systems
short_definition: A Management Information System (MIS) is a tool used by organizations to collect, analyze, and distribute information. It helps managers make informed decisions by providing them with insights into the company's performance, operations, and market trends. This system combines people, processes, and technology to create a clear picture of the organization's overall health and guide strategic planning.

name: medical devices
short_definition: A medical device is a tool used to diagnose, treat, or prevent medical conditions. It can be anything from a simple thermometer to a complex surgical robot. Medical devices are carefully regulated to ensure their safety and effectiveness before they are used on patients.

name: tsunamis
short_definition: A tsunami is a series of huge waves caused by sudden shifts on the ocean floor, often triggered by earthquakes or volcanic eruptions. These waves travel incredibly fast across deep water, but slow down as they approach shallower coastal areas.  As the waves reach the shore, their height increases dramatically, often causing devastating flooding and damage.

name: complex fluids
short_definition: A complex fluid is a mixture that has two different states of matter, like solid and liquid, existing together.  Because of this combination, complex fluids act in unusual ways when force is applied. They can behave like both a solid and a liquid, depending on the situation.

name: lipids
short_definition: Lipids are a broad category of naturally occurring molecules that include fats, waxes, and steroids. They are characterized by their poor solubility in water and their importance in various biological functions, such as energy storage, cell structure, and signaling.

name: sensors
short_definition: A sensor is a device that detects and measures physical changes in the world around us. It converts these changes, like light, temperature, or pressure, into signals that can be understood by machines.  These signals are then used to provide information about the environment or to control other devices.

name: embedded systems
short_definition: An embedded system is a specialized computer that is built into a larger device or machine. It's like a tiny brain that controls how the device works, handling tasks like controlling the flow of electricity, sensing changes, or communicating with other systems. These systems are found everywhere, from your smartphone to your car.

name: receptors
short_definition: A receptor is a protein within a cell that acts as a receiver for specific molecules called ligands.  When a ligand binds to a receptor, it triggers a response within the cell, such as a change in behavior or gene activity.  These receptors are essential for cells to sense and react to their surroundings, including signals from other cells.

name: stochastic partial differential equations
short_definition: A stochastic partial differential equation (SPDE) is a type of mathematical equation that uses randomness to model the behavior of systems. It extends the concept of a partial differential equation (PDE) by adding random elements, similar to how stochastic ordinary differential equations (SODEs) extend ordinary differential equations (ODEs).

name: adolescent health
short_definition: Adolescent health refers to the overall well-being of young people aged 10 to 19. It involves understanding the unique physical, mental, and social changes they experience during this crucial period of development.  Adolescent health focuses on promoting healthy habits, preventing health issues, and providing appropriate care when needed.  A holistic approach that considers the interplay of these factors is crucial for supporting adolescents during this important life stage.

name: international health
short_definition: International health aims to improve health and healthcare for everyone, regardless of where they live. It involves countries working together to strengthen healthcare systems and provide care, especially in places with limited resources.  This field prioritizes long-term solutions and addresses the factors that influence health, like social issues, the economy, and the environment.  International health recognizes that health issues are connected globally and that the world's interconnectedness impacts health outcomes.

name: environmental toxicology
short_definition: Environmental toxicology is the study of how harmful substances in the environment affect living things. It examines the impacts of pollutants, pesticides, and other toxins on individuals, groups of organisms, and entire ecosystems. A central focus is on how these substances move and change within the environment, including how they accumulate in living things. The goal is to understand and reduce the risks posed by these substances to the health and balance of our natural world.

name: neuroimmunology
short_definition: Neuroimmunology is the study of how the brain and the immune system communicate and influence each other. This field explores the complex relationship between these two systems, focusing on their development and how they work together in both healthy and diseased states.

name: resilience
short_definition: Resilience is the ability to cope with difficult situations and bounce back from setbacks. It means being able to adapt and thrive even when facing challenges, using them as opportunities to grow and learn. It's a skill that can be developed over time, helping you become stronger and more adaptable.

name: mathematical physics
short_definition: Mathematical physics is a branch of physics that uses mathematical tools to understand and solve problems in physics. It involves applying existing mathematical techniques to physical phenomena and developing new mathematical theories to better represent the nature of the physical world. This field focuses on the connection between mathematical concepts and physical realities, aiming to create a deeper understanding of the universe.

name: atomic physics
short_definition: Atomic physics explores the inner workings of atoms. It examines how electrons are arranged around the nucleus and how these arrangements change during interactions between atoms. This field focuses on the fundamental building blocks of matter and their behavior.

name: ancient philosophy
short_definition: Ancient philosophy refers to the philosophical ideas and systems that emerged in the ancient world, primarily in Greece and Rome. It covered a wide range of topics including the nature of reality, the search for knowledge, ethics, and political theory. Key figures and schools of thought include Socrates, Plato, Aristotle, Stoicism, and Epicureanism.

name: graphene
short_definition: Graphene is a single layer of carbon atoms arranged in a honeycomb pattern. It is essentially a thin sheet of graphite, with the name "graphene" combining "graphite" with "-ene," indicating the presence of double bonds.  This unique structure gives graphene exceptional strength, electrical conductivity, and transparency.

name: sustainable energy
short_definition: Sustainable energy is about meeting our energy needs today without harming the environment or compromising the ability of future generations to meet their own energy needs. It considers environmental, economic, and social factors to ensure a balanced and responsible approach to energy production and consumption.

name: protest
short_definition: A protest is a way for people to publicly express their disapproval of something, often with the goal of influencing change. It can involve a group of people gathering together to make their voices heard, or it can be a more individual action. The purpose is to show that people are unhappy with something and want it to change.

name: international development
short_definition: International development refers to the study and practice of addressing differences in economic and human well-being across the globe. It focuses on understanding and reducing disparities between countries, often categorized as "developed," "developing," and "least developed," and promoting improvements in areas like economic growth, poverty reduction, and quality of life.

name: approximation theory
short_definition: Approximation theory is about finding simpler ways to represent complex functions. This involves using simpler functions, like polynomials, to get close to the original function, while understanding how much error is introduced.  The idea of "best" approximation depends on what the function is used for and how accurate the result needs to be.

name: translational research
short_definition: Translational research is a type of scientific research that aims to bridge the gap between laboratory discoveries and real-world applications, ultimately improving human health. It involves translating basic scientific findings into new treatments, diagnostics, and interventions that can be used in clinical settings and communities. This process encompasses a range of stages, from initial laboratory research to clinical trials and the dissemination of new knowledge into everyday practice.

name: sustainable city
short_definition: A sustainable city is a city designed to be environmentally friendly, socially just, and economically viable. It aims to meet the needs of current residents while ensuring future generations have the same opportunities. Sustainable cities prioritize reducing pollution, conserving resources, and promoting renewable energy, all while fostering a high quality of life for everyone.

name: negotiation
short_definition: Negotiation is a conversation where people with different goals try to find a solution that everyone can agree on. It involves listening to each other, understanding each other's needs, and being willing to compromise. The goal is to reach a deal that benefits everyone involved.

name: soft matter
short_definition: Soft matter is a category of materials that can be easily changed in shape or structure by forces like heat or pressure. These materials are different from solids or liquids because they are affected by the same kind of energy that makes things warm.  This means that the natural tendency of things to become disordered (entropy) plays a big role in how they behave.

name: bioremediation
short_definition: Bioremediation is a natural cleaning process that uses living things like bacteria and fungi to clean up pollution in soil, water, and air. These organisms break down harmful substances into less dangerous ones, helping to restore the environment.

name: cell engineering
short_definition: Cell engineering is a scientific approach to modifying living cells. It involves changing the genetic makeup of cells, often using DNA technology, to alter their behavior or functions. This can include changing how cells grow, what they produce, or what they respond to.

name: density functional theory
short_definition: Density functional theory (DFT) is a method for calculating the properties of systems with many electrons, like atoms or molecules. Instead of directly dealing with the complex interactions of all electrons, DFT uses a simpler approach by focusing on the electron density, which describes how electrons are distributed in space.  This method, while less computationally demanding than other approaches, provides accurate predictions of a system's energy and other key properties.

name: ultrafast laser spectroscopy
short_definition: Ultrafast laser spectroscopy uses extremely short laser pulses to study how things change incredibly quickly. These pulses, lasting from a tiny fraction of a second to a billionth of a second, allow scientists to see the movements of electrons, atoms, and molecules in real-time.

name: synthetic biology
short_definition: Synthetic biology is a field of science that involves designing and building new biological systems using engineering principles. It focuses on creating new functions and abilities in organisms by modifying their existing components or introducing new ones. Researchers in this field utilize knowledge from different areas like biology, engineering, and computer science to create customized biological systems with specific applications.

name: numerical analysis
short_definition: Numerical analysis is a branch of mathematics that deals with finding approximate solutions to mathematical problems. Instead of finding exact solutions, numerical analysis uses algorithms to estimate solutions using numbers. These algorithms are designed to produce results that are close enough to the actual solution for practical purposes.

name: hardware security
short_definition: Hardware security focuses on protecting physical devices and systems from harm. It involves securing the hardware components, communication channels, and the underlying logic to prevent unauthorized access, tampering, and reverse engineering. This includes measures like encrypting devices and ensuring secure key storage. By addressing risks at the hardware level, it forms a foundational layer for overall system security.

name: built environment
short_definition: The built environment refers to the physical structures and systems created by humans that define our surroundings. It includes buildings, roads, bridges, and utilities, but also encompasses the spaces between these elements. This environment shapes how we live, work, and interact with each other, influencing our health, well-being, and quality of life.

name: volcanology
short_definition: Volcanology is the study of volcanoes and their related phenomena. It explores the processes that form volcanoes, the composition of volcanic rocks, and the dangers posed by volcanic eruptions. Volcanologists study these topics to understand the inner workings of volcanoes and to predict potential hazards.

name: calibration
short_definition: Calibration is the process of checking the accuracy of a measuring device by comparing its readings to a known, accurate standard. This standard can be another instrument, a device that produces a specific quantity, or a physical object. Calibration helps determine if the device is giving accurate measurements and identifies any errors that may need to be corrected.

name: biodiversity
short_definition: Biodiversity refers to the vast variety of life on Earth. It encompasses all living organisms, from microscopic bacteria to towering trees, and includes the ecosystems they inhabit. This diversity encompasses genetic differences within species, the multitude of species themselves, and the array of different ecosystems found across the globe.

name: population genetics
short_definition: Population genetics is the study of genetic variation within and between groups of organisms.  It explores how the frequency of genes changes over time due to factors like natural selection and random chance.  This field helps us understand how populations adapt, diversify, and evolve.

name: digital signal processing
short_definition: Digital signal processing (DSP) is the process of manipulating digital representations of signals, like sound or images. This involves converting continuous signals into discrete numerical samples and applying algorithms to these samples to achieve desired effects. DSP techniques can be used to enhance the quality of signals, extract information, or enable specific applications.

name: regenerative medicine
short_definition: Regenerative medicine is a branch of medicine that aims to heal damaged tissues and organs. It does this by either replacing damaged parts with new ones, like using stem cells or engineered tissues, or by stimulating the body's own healing processes. This exciting field holds the potential to cure a wide range of conditions and improve people's lives.

name: computational complexity
short_definition: Computational complexity is a way to measure how much time and memory an algorithm needs to solve a problem. It's like measuring how long a recipe takes and how many ingredients you need. The complexity is often described using a mathematical function that shows how the resources grow as the size of the problem gets bigger.

name: dramaturgy
short_definition: Dramaturgy is the art of creating and shaping a story for the stage.  It involves understanding the elements of dramatic writing, like plot, characters, and dialogue, and figuring out how to effectively bring them to life in a performance. Dramaturgy helps create a solid foundation for a play, often adapting stories or ideas to connect with audiences today.

name: sound
short_definition: Sound is a type of energy that travels through the air or other materials in waves.  These waves cause vibrations that our ears detect, resulting in the sensation of hearing.  Sound can be described as a physical phenomenon involving pressure changes in the air or as the auditory experience we perceive.

name: aerodynamics
short_definition: Aerodynamics is the science of how air moves and how it affects objects that travel through it. It studies the forces that air exerts on things like airplane wings or cars, and how these forces affect their movement.  Aerodynamics uses math, experiments, and computer simulations to understand how air behaves.

name: sport management
short_definition: Sport management is a business field focused on running sports and recreational organizations. It involves a range of skills, including planning, budgeting, and leading, to manage all aspects of the sports industry. This field has evolved from physical education and now incorporates knowledge from history, sociology, and economics.

name: membrane biology
short_definition: Membrane biology is the study of the structure, function, and dynamics of biological membranes. These membranes, found both within cells and surrounding them, are responsible for keeping toxic substances out, controlling the movement of molecules, and separating different cellular processes.

name: drug resistance
short_definition: Drug resistance happens when a harmful organism, like a bacteria or cancer cell, changes so that a medicine no longer works against it.  This happens because the organism's genes change, making it harder for the medicine to target it or allowing the organism to get rid of the medicine.

name: material culture
short_definition: Material culture refers to the physical objects that people create and use within a society. These objects, like tools, clothes, art, and buildings, represent the tangible aspects of a culture.  Material culture helps us understand the values, beliefs, and ways of life of a group of people, both past and present.

name: natural language processing
short_definition: Natural language processing (NLP) is a field of computer science that allows computers to understand and process human language, like English or Spanish. It helps computers analyze, understand, and even generate text and speech just like people do. NLP uses advanced techniques like machine learning to achieve this.

name: autoimmunity
short_definition: Autoimmunity is a condition where the body's immune system, normally responsible for fighting off infections, mistakenly attacks its own healthy cells and tissues. This happens when the immune system loses its ability to differentiate between "self" and "non-self," leading to an immune response against the body's own components.

name: technology transfer
short_definition: Technology transfer is the process of sharing knowledge and inventions from one person or organization to another. It helps to move new ideas and discoveries from the lab to the real world, making them useful for everyone. This process often involves protecting the rights of the inventor through patents or copyrights.  Technology transfer is an important way to encourage collaboration and drive progress in society.

name: population growth
short_definition: Population growth refers to the increase or decrease in the number of individuals within a population over a specific period. It is influenced by factors like birth rates, death rates, and migration patterns. A positive growth rate means the population is increasing, while a negative rate indicates a decline.

name: biometrics
short_definition: Biometrics is the use of unique, measurable traits of a person's body or behavior for identification. These traits can include fingerprints, facial features, iris patterns, or even the way someone types. This technology helps verify a person's identity in a more reliable way than traditional methods like passwords.

name: materiality
short_definition: **Materiality** is about how important a financial item is.  It helps accountants and auditors decide whether something needs to be reported or changed in a company's financial statements. If an item is material, it means it could influence someone's decision about the company based on its financial information.

name: rheumatology
short_definition: Rheumatology is a branch of medicine focusing on diagnosing and treating diseases that affect the joints, muscles, and bones. These conditions, often called rheumatic diseases, involve inflammation and can cause pain, stiffness, swelling, and even deformities.  Rheumatologists are doctors who specialize in these conditions.

name: molecular modelling
short_definition: Molecular modelling is a technique that uses computer simulations to understand how molecules behave. It involves representing molecules and their interactions at the atomic level, allowing scientists to study their properties and predict how they will act in different situations.

name: planetary science
short_definition: Planetary science is the study of planets and their surrounding systems. It investigates how these systems formed, their functions, and the interactions between their components. Planetary scientists use knowledge from various fields like astronomy, geology, and physics to understand planets and their environments.

name: music education
short_definition: Music education is the field of training educators to teach music. It covers both practical skills and research about effective music teaching methods. Music educators work in various settings, from elementary schools to music institutions, and aim to develop students' musical skills, knowledge, and appreciation.

name: magnetism
short_definition: Magnetism is a force that attracts or repels objects.  This force arises from the movement of electric charges and the magnetic properties of tiny particles within materials. All materials exhibit some form of magnetism, but some, like iron, are strongly magnetic, while others are only weakly magnetic.

name: pediatric urology
short_definition: Pediatric urology is a specialized area of medicine that focuses on the health of children's urinary and reproductive systems.  These doctors are trained to diagnose, treat, and manage a wide range of conditions affecting these organs, from simple infections to complex birth defects. They have the specific expertise to provide care tailored to the unique needs of children.

name: speech perception
short_definition: Speech perception is the process of listening to and understanding spoken language. It involves taking in sounds, recognizing different speech sounds, and putting them together to form words and sentences.  This process is essential for communication and allows us to make sense of the spoken world around us.

name: depression
short_definition: Depression is a mental health condition that causes a person to feel persistently sad, hopeless, and lose interest in things they used to enjoy. It can affect their everyday life and make it hard to function.

name: analytical chemistry
short_definition: Analytical chemistry is the study of the composition and structure of matter. It involves identifying the different components of a substance and determining how much of each component is present. Analytical chemists use a variety of methods and instruments to separate, identify, and measure these components.

name: computational biology
short_definition: Computational biology is a field that uses computers to study living things. It combines biology, computer science, and mathematics to analyze biological data, create models of how biological systems work, and simulate these systems. This helps scientists understand how living organisms function and how they interact with each other.

name: corporate governance
short_definition: Corporate governance is the framework that ensures companies are run effectively and ethically. It involves setting rules and guidelines for how a company is managed, including its relationship with shareholders, employees, and other stakeholders.  These rules aim to protect the interests of all parties involved and ensure the company operates responsibly.

name: schizophrenia
short_definition: Schizophrenia is a serious mental illness that causes people to lose touch with reality.  They may experience hallucinations, which are seeing or hearing things that aren't there, and delusions, which are false beliefs.  Schizophrenia can also lead to disorganized thinking and behavior, making it difficult to function in daily life. This disorder usually starts in young adulthood and can have a significant impact on a person's ability to work and socialize.

name: computational geometry
short_definition: Computational geometry is a field of computer science that focuses on creating algorithms for solving geometric problems. It explores how to represent and manipulate geometric objects using computers, focusing on developing efficient methods for dealing with large amounts of data.  This field involves analyzing the performance of these algorithms and their effectiveness in addressing complex geometric challenges.

name: community engagement
short_definition: Community engagement is when people actively work together with organizations to make their communities better. It's more than just living in a place; it means participating in projects, sharing ideas, and working together to solve problems. This collaboration helps improve the community's well-being and empowers its members.

name: wellness
short_definition: Wellness is the state of being in good health and feeling good about life. It's not just about being free from illness, but also about feeling happy, balanced, and satisfied. Wellness means taking care of your physical, mental, and emotional health, and finding ways to live a fulfilling life.

name: children's literature
short_definition: Children's literature is a broad category of written works and illustrations designed for young people. It includes both classic and modern stories, picture books, fairy tales, and other materials meant to entertain and educate children.

name: superconductivity
short_definition: Superconductivity is a special property of some materials where they lose all resistance to electrical current when cooled below a certain temperature. This means electricity can flow through them without any loss of energy.

name: sustainable products
short_definition: Sustainable products are items designed to have minimal negative impact on the environment and society. They are made with eco-friendly materials, manufactured using responsible processes, and consider their impact even after they are no longer used. This ensures they benefit people, the planet, and the economy throughout their entire life cycle.

name: network science
short_definition: Network science is the study of how things are connected. It examines complex networks, like social networks or computer networks, by focusing on the elements (nodes) and their relationships (links). This field combines knowledge from many areas, like mathematics and sociology, to understand how networks function and to predict how they might change.

name: water resource policy
short_definition: Water resource policy is a set of rules and guidelines designed to manage how we use, protect, and conserve water.  It ensures that we have enough clean water for everyone, including people, animals, and plants, while also keeping our water sources healthy. These policies consider various factors like the environment, population needs, and economic development.

name: bias
short_definition: Bias is a tendency to favor one thing over another, often unfairly. It can be a personal preference, an unconscious prejudice, or a systematic error in how information is gathered or analyzed.  This can lead to inaccurate conclusions and biased judgments.

name: social work
short_definition: Social work is a profession and study that aims to help people and improve society. It focuses on addressing individual and community needs and challenges, striving for social justice and equality for everyone.  Social workers use knowledge from various fields to understand and address social problems and work towards positive change.

name: existentialism
short_definition: Existentialism is a philosophy that focuses on the individual's experience of living in a world without inherent meaning or purpose. It emphasizes the freedom and responsibility we have to create our own meaning and values through our choices and actions. Existentialists believe that we are thrown into existence, and it is up to us to find our own way in a sometimes absurd and indifferent world.

name: anatomy
short_definition: Anatomy is the study of the body's structure. It explores how the parts of an organism are organized and connected, from large organs to tiny cells and tissues.  Anatomy helps us understand the physical makeup of living things and how they function.

name: audiology
short_definition: Audiology is the study of hearing and balance. It focuses on understanding and treating problems with these senses, which can occur at any age.  Audiologists use special tests to figure out how well someone hears and identify any issues. They then create plans to help people manage these challenges, sometimes using devices like hearing aids or cochlear implants.

name: chromatin
short_definition: Chromatin is a substance found in the nucleus of cells that consists of DNA tightly wrapped around proteins called histones. This packaging helps organize the long DNA molecules and prevents them from becoming tangled. Chromatin can exist in different forms, with some regions more tightly packed than others, which plays a role in controlling how genes are accessed and used.

name: neuroanatomy
short_definition: Neuroanatomy is the study of the nervous system's structure and how it relates to its functions. It explores both the large-scale features of the brain and spinal cord, as well as the microscopic interactions between nerve cells and supporting cells.  Neuroanatomists examine how the nervous system is organized and connected, providing a foundation for understanding how it controls our thoughts, actions, and sensations.

name: functional genomics
short_definition: Functional genomics is the study of how genes and their surrounding DNA regions work together to create different traits and processes within an organism.  It focuses on understanding the dynamic interactions of genes and proteins, particularly how they are expressed and regulated in specific contexts like development or disease. This field uses high-throughput technologies to analyze these activities on a large scale, providing a comprehensive view of how the genome functions.

name: star formation
short_definition: Star formation is the process where dense areas within vast clouds of gas and dust in space, called molecular clouds, collapse under their own gravity. This collapse leads to the formation of new stars.

name: social determinants of health
short_definition: Social determinants of health are the conditions in our surroundings that impact our health, well-being, and quality of life. These factors include things like where we live, our income level, access to education and jobs, and even exposure to racism or violence.  They play a major role in shaping our overall health and well-being.

name: marketing strategy
short_definition: A marketing strategy is a detailed plan that outlines how a company will use its resources to reach its target customers and achieve its marketing goals. This includes deciding where to advertise, what messaging to use, and how to build relationships with customers. A strong marketing strategy helps a company stand out from its competitors and grow its business.

name: molecular neuroscience
short_definition: Molecular neuroscience is a field that examines the nervous systems of animals by applying principles of molecular biology. It focuses on understanding the molecular structures, signaling processes, and genetic influences that govern the development, function, and health of the nervous system. This area of study contributes to understanding conditions like neuroplasticity and neurodegenerative diseases.

name: soil
short_definition: Soil is the top layer of Earth's surface that supports plant life. It's made up of tiny rock particles, decayed plant and animal matter, water, and air.  Soil is constantly changing as it is influenced by weather, living things, and the passage of time.

name: moral psychology
short_definition: Moral psychology is the study of how people think, feel, and act in situations involving right and wrong. It examines the factors that influence our moral judgments, like our beliefs, emotions, and experiences. This field draws on insights from psychology, neuroscience, and philosophy to understand the complexities of human morality.

name: fishery
short_definition: A fishery is the act of catching or farming aquatic life, like fish, shrimp, or even seals. It's both the activity itself and the specific area where the fishing takes place. This can involve catching wild fish in the ocean or freshwater, or raising fish in a controlled environment like a fish farm.

name: cognitive development
short_definition: Cognitive development refers to the process of how children learn to think, solve problems, and understand the world around them.  It involves the growth of their brain, skills, and knowledge, allowing them to develop more complex thinking abilities.  As children mature, they progress through different stages of cognitive development, influenced by both their genes and their environment.

name: epistemology
short_definition: Epistemology is the study of knowledge. It explores how we know what we know, the nature of knowledge itself, and the limits of our understanding. Epistemologists investigate the sources of our beliefs, how we justify those beliefs, and the structure of our knowledge systems.

name: biomanufacturing
short_definition: Biomanufacturing uses living organisms or their parts to create useful products. This process involves cultivating cells, often genetically modified, in controlled environments.  These products can be biomaterials, biomolecules, or other substances with applications in various industries.

name: chemistry education
short_definition: Chemistry education is the study of how people learn and teach chemistry. It's a part of science education that focuses on understanding how students learn best and finding the most effective ways to teach chemistry concepts.

name: paleoecology
short_definition: Paleoecology is the study of ancient environments and the relationships between the organisms that lived in them. By examining fossils and their geological context, scientists can understand how ecosystems have changed over millions of years and how past organisms interacted with their surroundings.

name: cognition
short_definition: Cognition is the way our brains process information.  It includes how we learn new things, remember things we've learned, pay attention, and solve problems.  Cognition is how we make sense of the world around us and use what we know to make decisions.

name: energy storage
short_definition: Energy storage is the process of saving energy for later use. It involves capturing energy from sources like the sun, wind, or fossil fuels and transforming it into a storable form, like in a battery or a hydroelectric dam. This allows us to use energy when we need it, even if the source isn't available at that moment.

name: audit
short_definition: An audit is a thorough examination of an organization's or individual's financial information or other activities. It's performed by trained professionals who review evidence, check facts, and ultimately determine if the information is accurate and reliable. This process helps ensure that the information is honest and complies with all relevant rules.

name: program analysis
short_definition: Program analysis is a way to automatically examine how a computer program works. This analysis helps determine if the program is correct, reliable, safe, and functions properly.  It can be used to improve the program's speed and efficiency or ensure it performs as intended.

name: hiv
short_definition: HIV, or human immunodeficiency virus, is a virus that attacks the body's immune system, specifically targeting cells that help fight off infections.  HIV infection weakens the immune system over time, making individuals more susceptible to various illnesses and infections.  This weakened state is known as AIDS, or acquired immunodeficiency syndrome.

name: sustainable urbanism
short_definition: Sustainable urbanism is about building cities in a way that helps them thrive for generations to come. It focuses on using resources wisely, reducing pollution, and making sure cities are healthy and fair for everyone who lives there.

name: motivation
short_definition: Motivation is the force that drives us to act. It's the reason we choose to do certain things, and how much effort we put into them. Motivation comes from inside us, like enjoyment, or from outside, like rewards.

name: diagnosis
short_definition: Diagnosis is the process of figuring out what is wrong with something. It involves carefully examining signs and symptoms, and using knowledge and experience to determine the cause.  This process is used in many fields, like medicine, where doctors diagnose illnesses, or in engineering, where engineers diagnose problems with machines.

name: quantum mechanics
short_definition: Quantum mechanics is a fundamental theory in physics that explains how things work at the tiniest level, like atoms and smaller particles. It's different from how things work in the world we see, where everything is predictable. In quantum mechanics, things are more uncertain, and things can act like both waves and particles at the same time.

name: civic engagement
short_definition: Civic engagement is when people work together to solve problems that affect their community. It can involve volunteering, joining organizations, voting, or simply speaking up about issues that matter.

name: environmental law
short_definition: Environmental law is a set of rules and regulations that aim to protect the environment, human health, and natural resources. It covers a wide range of issues, like pollution, waste management, and resource conservation. These laws are designed to ensure that human activities don't harm the environment and to promote sustainable practices for the benefit of present and future generations.

name: cosmochemistry
short_definition: Cosmochemistry is the study of the chemicals found in the universe. It focuses on how these chemicals formed and changed over time, from the earliest moments of the universe to the formation of planets and stars.

name: chemical kinetics
short_definition: Chemical kinetics is the study of how fast chemical reactions happen.  It looks at the factors that influence the speed of a reaction, such as temperature and the amount of reactants present.  Chemical kinetics helps us understand the steps involved in a reaction and how they occur.

name: mathematical analysis
short_definition: Mathematical analysis is a branch of mathematics that explores the behavior of functions, focusing on concepts like continuity, limits, and infinite processes. It includes topics like differentiation, integration, and the study of sequences and series. Mathematical analysis builds upon the foundation of calculus, delving deeper into the theoretical underpinnings of these concepts.

name: criminology
short_definition: Criminology is the study of crime and its causes. It explores why people commit crimes and how society responds to criminal behavior. Criminologists use knowledge from different fields like psychology, law, and sociology to understand crime and develop ways to prevent it.

name: human brain
short_definition: The human brain is the control center of our body, responsible for everything from thinking and feeling to movement and breathing. It is made up of different parts, each with its own unique job.  The brain receives information from the world around us, processes it, and then sends instructions to the body.

name: transmission
short_definition: Transmission refers to the act of moving something from one place to another. This could be anything from a physical object to energy, information, or even diseases. The process involves a sender, a receiver, and a pathway or medium through which the transfer takes place.

name: scalability
short_definition: Scalability is the ability of a system to handle a growing workload without slowing down or breaking.  It means the system can smoothly adjust its capacity as needed, like adding more servers or workers, to meet increased demands.

name: rapid prototyping
short_definition: Rapid prototyping is a way to quickly create physical models of products using computer designs. It often uses 3D printing to build the model layer by layer, allowing designers to test and refine their ideas before mass production.

name: language acquisition
short_definition: Language acquisition is the process of learning how to understand and use a language. It involves developing the skills to recognize sounds, understand words and their meanings, and put them together into sentences to communicate. This process starts early in life and continues throughout a person's development.

name: stochastic process
short_definition: A stochastic process is a mathematical model used to describe systems that change over time in a way that involves chance. It's like a series of random variables, where each variable represents the state of the system at a specific point in time. This means that the future behavior of the system is uncertain, but we can still understand its probabilities and patterns.

name: human migration
short_definition: Human migration is the movement of people from one place to another, with the intention of staying there for a long time or permanently. It can happen within a country or across borders. People migrate for various reasons, such as seeking better opportunities, escaping difficult situations, or simply wanting a change.

name: neuro-ophthalmology
short_definition: Neuro-ophthalmology is a specialized field of medicine that focuses on the connection between the brain and the eyes. These doctors diagnose and treat eye problems caused by disorders affecting the nervous system, such as brain tumors, strokes, or multiple sclerosis. They have specialized training in both neurology and ophthalmology.

name: visual culture
short_definition: Visual culture explores how images and visual representations shape our understanding of the world. It examines everything from advertising and architecture to fashion and film, recognizing that visual communication plays a crucial role in shaping our beliefs and values.

name: assistive technology
short_definition: Assistive technology refers to tools and devices that help people with disabilities perform daily tasks and live more independently.  These tools can be simple, like adapted utensils, or more complex, like voice recognition software.  Assistive technology aims to make everyday activities like communication, mobility, and self-care easier and more accessible.

name: ethics
short_definition: Ethics is a set of principles that guide us in determining what is right and wrong. It helps us understand our obligations to ourselves and others, and how to live a good and meaningful life.

name: curiosity
short_definition: Curiosity is a natural desire to learn and explore. It's the feeling of wanting to know more about something and it pushes us to ask questions and seek out new experiences.  It's what makes us interested in the world around us and motivates us to learn new things.

name: geochemistry
short_definition: Geochemistry is the study of the chemical composition and processes within Earth's systems, such as the crust and oceans. It uses chemical principles to understand how Earth's materials interact and change over time.

name: hepatology
short_definition: Hepatology is the branch of medicine that studies, prevents, diagnoses, and manages diseases affecting the liver, gallbladder, biliary tree, and pancreas.

name: sculpture
short_definition: A sculpture base is the foundation upon which a sculpture stands. It provides support and stability for the artwork, and can also be an integral part of the sculpture's design. Bases can be made from a variety of materials, such as wood, stone, metal, or even glass, and can be simple or elaborate in form.

name: fintech
short_definition: Fintech, short for financial technology, is a broad term for companies that use innovative technology to improve and change how financial services are delivered. It involves creating new ways for people and businesses to manage their money, from simple things like mobile banking to more complex areas like cryptocurrency.

name: political economy
short_definition: Political economy is the study of how the economy and the government interact. It looks at how laws, policies, and institutions affect things like markets, jobs, money, and fairness. It considers how these two systems influence each other and work together to shape how our society functions.

name: political philosophy
short_definition: Political philosophy is a field of thinking that explores the ideas and principles behind political systems. It examines questions about how power should be used, what makes a government just, and how society should be organized. Political philosophy focuses on what should be, rather than simply describing what is, aiming to understand the ideal and ethical foundations of political life.

name: symmetry
short_definition: Symmetry is a concept that describes a balanced arrangement of parts. It means that an object or design can be divided into two or more identical parts that mirror each other. This can involve a line of division, a center point, or an axis of rotation.

name: trauma
short_definition: Trauma is a deeply upsetting experience that can cause significant emotional and sometimes physical distress. It can be triggered by a wide range of events, including accidents, violence, abuse, natural disasters, and the loss of a loved one.  The effects of trauma can linger long after the event itself, manifesting in a variety of ways, such as intense emotions, flashbacks, relationship difficulties, and physical symptoms.

name: quantum information science
short_definition: Quantum information science is a field that explores how the principles of quantum mechanics can be used to improve the handling of information. It combines elements of physics, mathematics, computer science, and engineering to study how information can be stored, processed, and transmitted in new and more efficient ways.

name: combustion
short_definition: Combustion is a chemical process where a substance reacts with oxygen, releasing energy in the form of heat and light. This reaction happens quickly, and the result is usually a flame.  The process is often referred to as burning.

name: electrochemistry
short_definition: Electrochemistry is the study of how chemical reactions and electricity interact. It examines reactions where electrons move between an electrode and a liquid solution, creating a measurable electrical charge. This electron transfer sets electrochemical reactions apart from regular chemical reactions.

name: voluntary sector
short_definition: The voluntary sector is made up of organizations that are not run by the government or for profit. These groups work to help people and make the world a better place. They are often called non-profits or charities, and they focus on things like social services, animal welfare, and environmental protection.

name: medical imaging
short_definition: Medical imaging is a way to see inside the human body without surgery. It uses different technologies to create pictures of bones, organs, and other structures. These pictures help doctors diagnose illnesses, monitor treatment progress, and plan surgeries.

name: personality
short_definition: Personality is the unique and lasting combination of how a person thinks, feels, and acts, shaping their way of interacting with the world.  It's a blend of traits, interests, and motivations that influences how we behave, and though relatively stable, it can change and grow over time.

name: psychoanalysis
short_definition: Psychoanalysis is a type of therapy focused on understanding and treating mental health issues. It emphasizes the impact of unconscious thoughts, feelings, and experiences, particularly from childhood, on our behavior and well-being. Through conversations and exploring dreams, the goal is to uncover and work through these hidden conflicts, leading to greater self-awareness and personal growth.

name: water supply
short_definition: A water supply is the system that provides water for a community, like a city or town. It includes things like reservoirs, tunnels, and pipelines to get the water from its source to where it's needed.

name: mechanical property
short_definition: **Mechanical properties** describe how a material reacts when a force is applied to it. These properties are important for understanding how strong, stiff, and durable a material will be.

name: microsurgery
short_definition: Microsurgery is a type of surgery that uses powerful magnifying tools and special techniques to work on very small blood vessels and nerves.  This allows surgeons to reconnect severed parts, move tissue from one place to another, and repair injuries that damage these tiny structures.

name: computer music
short_definition: Computer music is a broad term that describes the use of computers in creating music. This can involve using software to generate sounds, manipulate existing recordings, or even write entire pieces of music.

name: diplomacy
short_definition: Diplomacy is the art of communicating and negotiating between different countries and groups to build relationships, solve problems, and achieve common goals. It involves talking, making deals, and working together peacefully to find solutions instead of resorting to violence.

name: tumor microenvironment
short_definition: The tumor microenvironment (TME) is the complex neighborhood surrounding a tumor, filled with different types of cells, including cancer cells, immune cells, and support cells. It also includes molecules that signal between cells and the scaffolding that holds everything together. This environment is constantly changing and influences how the tumor grows, spreads, and responds to treatments.

name: gender identity
short_definition: Gender identity is how someone feels about their own gender, whether they feel like a man, woman, both, or neither. This sense of self is deeply personal and can be different from the sex they were assigned at birth. It's a core part of who someone is, and it helps them understand their place in the world.

name: molecular genetics
short_definition: Molecular genetics is a branch of biology that studies the relationship between genes and their observable characteristics in organisms. It examines how variations in DNA structure and expression lead to different traits. This field uses a variety of techniques to understand the structure and function of genes within an organism's complete set of genetic material, known as the genome.

name: optical properties
short_definition: Optical properties describe how a material interacts with light. They tell us how much light passes through, how much is absorbed, and how much is reflected or scattered.  These properties include characteristics like refractive index, absorption, and reflectance.

name: solar energy conversion
short_definition: Solar energy conversion is the process of transforming sunlight into usable forms of energy, such as electricity, fuels, and heat. It involves technologies that capture light and use it to drive chemical reactions or generate electrical currents. These technologies range from traditional solar panels to more advanced methods like artificial photosynthesis, which mimics the way plants convert sunlight into energy.

name: value theory
short_definition: Value theory is a field that explores what makes things valuable and how we determine their worth. It investigates the nature of "goodness," encompassing both moral and natural goods. Value theory aims to understand the principles that guide human judgments about what is good, worthwhile, and desirable.

name: nanomaterials
short_definition: Nanomaterials are materials that are incredibly small, measured in nanometers. A nanometer is one billionth of a meter, making these materials much smaller than the width of a human hair. These materials can be made up of single particles, clusters of particles, or have internal structures at the nanoscale.

name: trust
short_definition: Trust is the belief that someone or something is reliable and honest. It means being willing to rely on their actions, words, or decisions, even though there's always a chance they could let you down. Trust is essential for building relationships, working together, and creating a sense of security in our interactions with others.

name: tax avoidance
short_definition: Tax avoidance is the legal practice of minimizing your tax liability by using strategies allowed by the law. This can involve claiming deductions and credits, investing in tax-advantaged options, or finding loopholes within the tax code. While legal, tax avoidance can sometimes raise ethical concerns, especially when it involves large corporations paying very little tax despite making significant profits.

name: injury prevention
short_definition: Injury prevention is about taking steps to avoid injuries, especially those caused by accidents or violence.  It focuses on understanding the causes of injuries and developing ways to prevent them from happening in the first place. This involves educating people about safety, making changes to environments to make them safer, and creating laws and policies that promote safety.

name: environmental monitoring
short_definition: Environmental monitoring is the process of systematically observing and analyzing the condition of the environment.  It involves collecting data on factors like air, water, and soil quality to understand the current state of the environment and identify changes over time.  This information helps us understand the impact of human activities on the environment and make informed decisions to protect it.

name: breast cancer
short_definition: Breast cancer is a disease where abnormal cells grow uncontrollably in the breast tissue.  It primarily affects women, but men can also develop it. The cause is unknown, but factors like genetics, lifestyle choices, and hormones can increase the risk.  Symptoms may include lumps, skin changes, or nipple discharge.

name: family planning
short_definition: Family planning is about deciding when and how many children you want to have. It involves using methods like contraception to control when you get pregnant and preparing for having children.  Family planning helps people make choices about their reproductive health and achieve their desired family size.

name: caribbean studies
short_definition: Caribbean studies is the study of the Caribbean region, focusing on its history, society, politics, culture, and economics.  It examines the diverse people, communities, and environments of the islands and surrounding coastlines, including their pre-colonial, colonial, and modern experiences.

name: complex analysis
short_definition: Complex analysis is a branch of mathematics that studies functions of complex numbers.  It focuses on analytic functions, which are functions that can be represented by infinite power series, known as Taylor series. This means these functions are smooth and well-behaved, allowing for powerful tools and techniques to be used in their analysis.

name: sociocultural anthropology
short_definition: Sociocultural anthropology is the study of how people in different cultures understand the world and interact with each other. It looks at how shared beliefs and values shape how people act in society and how power influences those interactions.  Sociocultural anthropologists study both the past and present, recognizing that cultures are constantly changing and influenced by globalization.

name: omics
short_definition: Omics is a broad term for scientific fields that study all the molecules in a living thing. These fields aim to understand how these molecules work together to create the structure, function, and behavior of an organism.

name: quantum materials
short_definition: Quantum materials are a special type of material that behave in ways that cannot be explained by traditional physics.  These materials exhibit unusual properties like quantum entanglement and fluctuations, which arise from the complex interaction of various components within the material.

name: galaxy formation and evolution
short_definition: Galaxy formation and evolution is the process by which the universe transitioned from a uniform state to one filled with diverse galaxies.  It involves the creation of the first galaxies, their changes over time, and the forces driving their varied shapes and structures. Gravity plays a crucial role in this process, pulling matter together through clustering and mergers to form the galaxies we see today.

name: verification
short_definition: Verification is the process of making sure something is correct or true. It involves checking if information is consistent, comparing it to known facts, and ensuring that any claims are supported by evidence. This helps to determine if something is reliable and accurate.

name: authenticity
short_definition: **Authenticity** is the quality of being genuine and real. It means being true to oneself and not pretending to be someone or something else.  Authenticity implies a lack of artificiality or deception.

name: survey methodology
short_definition: Survey methodology is the science behind creating and conducting surveys. It covers everything from choosing the right people to ask to designing clear questions, collecting accurate data, and drawing meaningful conclusions about a larger group. The goal is to make sure surveys are reliable, unbiased, and reflect the real world.

name: cultural history
short_definition: Cultural history explores how people lived in the past, examining their beliefs, traditions, and everyday experiences. It goes beyond political or economic events, looking at things like food, clothing, and rituals to understand what life was like for different groups. Cultural history connects these aspects to the present and explores how they are linked across different cultures.

name: fashion
short_definition: Fashion is about how we dress and decorate ourselves. It's a mix of what's popular, what looks good, and what reflects our personality. It's also about the clothes, accessories, and styles that are created and sold.  Fashion is a powerful way to show who we are and how we feel.

name: sociolinguistics
short_definition: Sociolinguistics is the study of how language is used and affected by society. It explores how things like culture, social groups, and context influence how people speak and what they say. This includes looking at how language changes depending on who you're talking to and the situation you're in.

name: creative writing
short_definition: Creative writing is a broad term that refers to writing that uses imagination and storytelling techniques to express ideas and emotions. It includes genres like fiction, poetry, screenplays, and playwriting, and focuses on crafting narratives, developing characters, and exploring literary themes in original ways.

name: group theory
short_definition: Group theory is a branch of mathematics that focuses on studying groups. A group is a set of elements with a specific operation that combines them, satisfying certain rules. These rules ensure that the operation is closed, associative, has an identity element, and each element has an inverse.

name: text mining
short_definition: Text mining is the process of extracting useful information from unstructured text, such as documents, articles, and social media posts. It involves transforming this text into a structured format, allowing you to identify patterns and insights that might otherwise be hidden.

name: sleep
short_definition: Sleep is a natural state of rest and unconsciousness that occurs regularly in living beings. During sleep, our body and mind relax, our brain activity changes, and we experience dreams.  Sleep is crucial for restoring energy, repairing our bodies, and maintaining our physical and mental health.

name: visualization
short_definition: Visualization is the process of creating visual representations, like charts, diagrams, or images, to make information easier to understand and analyze. It helps us see patterns, trends, and relationships in data that might be difficult to grasp with just words or numbers.

name: geochronology
short_definition: Geochronology is the study of the Earth's history, specifically focused on determining the ages of rocks and rock formations. This science uses various methods, including examining the decay of radioactive isotopes and analyzing stable isotope ratios, to establish a timeline of geological events. By understanding the age of rocks, scientists can reconstruct the Earth's past and its evolution over time.

name: survival analysis
short_definition: Survival analysis is a statistical method for understanding how long something lasts before a specific event occurs. It helps determine the probability of an event happening over time, taking into account factors that influence how long something survives.

name: obesity
short_definition: Obesity is a health condition where a person has too much body fat. This excess fat can lead to various health problems. Doctors use a number called BMI (Body Mass Index) to measure obesity. A BMI over 30 is considered obese, while a BMI between 25 and 30 is overweight.

name: algebraic topology
short_definition: Algebraic topology is a field of mathematics that uses algebraic methods to study and classify shapes. It aims to create algebraic descriptions, called invariants, that capture the essential features of a shape. These invariants can be used to distinguish between different shapes or to determine if two shapes are essentially the same, even if they look different.

name: social philosophy
short_definition: Social philosophy is a branch of philosophy that explores the ethical foundation of society. It examines the values that shape social institutions, behaviors, and power structures. It aims to understand how social contexts influence political, legal, moral, and cultural issues, and to develop new theoretical frameworks for addressing questions of justice, democracy, and human rights.

name: predictive analytics
short_definition: Predictive analytics uses data to anticipate future outcomes. It analyzes patterns in past data to forecast trends and events, which can be helpful in making informed decisions. By identifying potential scenarios, it helps businesses make strategic choices and manage risks.

name: psychiatric epidemiology
short_definition: Psychiatric epidemiology is the study of mental disorders within populations. It focuses on understanding the prevalence, distribution, and causes of these disorders, considering factors like genetics, environment, and social influences.

name: harmonic analysis
short_definition: Harmonic analysis is a mathematical field that focuses on understanding how functions can be broken down into their component frequencies. It uses tools like the Fourier transform to represent functions in terms of these frequencies, providing insights into their underlying structure.

name: physical geography
short_definition: Physical geography is the study of Earth's natural features and processes. It explores how the atmosphere, water, living things, and Earth's solid surface interact.  This branch of geography focuses on the natural world,  unlike human geography, which examines the human-made environment.

name: tourism
short_definition: Tourism is the act of traveling to a place outside of your usual environment for a period of time, often for leisure or business purposes. It involves using commercial services for accommodation, transportation, and activities, and can include both domestic and international travel.

name: quality management
short_definition: Quality management is a system for ensuring that products and services consistently meet high standards. It involves planning how to achieve quality, assuring that plans are followed, controlling the process to prevent problems, and constantly improving the system to reach even higher levels of excellence.

name: evolutionary ecology
short_definition: Evolutionary ecology is the study of how species evolve in response to their environment. It examines how interactions between species and their surroundings drive adaptations, which in turn shape the variety of life on Earth. By combining principles of ecology and evolution, this field explores how the history of life influences the present-day relationships between organisms and their ecosystems.

name: evolutionary psychology
short_definition: Evolutionary psychology is a field of study that explores how our minds and behaviors have been shaped by natural selection over millions of years. It suggests that our brains are designed with specific mechanisms that helped our ancestors survive and reproduce in their environments. These mechanisms, like our instincts and emotions, are thought to be adaptations that have been passed down through generations.

name: energy policy
short_definition: Energy policy refers to a government's plan to manage the production, distribution, and use of energy within its borders. It involves setting rules and incentives to guide the energy sector, impacting everything from where we get our power to how we use it in our homes and businesses.

name: biophotonics
short_definition: Biophotonics is a field that combines biology and photonics, using light to study and interact with living things. It uses light to capture images, analyze, and manipulate biological materials from tiny molecules to whole tissues. The techniques are often non-invasive, meaning they don't harm the samples, making them useful for research and medicine.

name: glycobiology
short_definition: Glycobiology is the study of sugars, specifically their structure, how they are made, and what they do in living things.  These sugars, called glycans, are found attached to cells and proteins, and they play important roles in how organisms develop and function.

name: maternal health
short_definition: Maternal health is about the well-being of women during pregnancy, childbirth, and the period after giving birth. It aims to ensure both mothers and babies are healthy and happy. This includes things like prenatal care, labor and delivery, and support after the baby is born.

name: model selection
short_definition: Model selection is the process of choosing the best model from a group of possible models. This choice is made based on how well each model performs on a given dataset, with the goal of finding the model that best explains the data or predicts future outcomes.

name: fraud
short_definition: Fraud is a deliberate act of trickery used to gain an unfair advantage, usually involving money or someone's rights. This deception is illegal and can lead to serious consequences like lawsuits or jail time.  Even if no money is lost, fraudulent actions can still be part of other crimes.

name: design optimization
short_definition: Design optimization is a process engineers use to find the best possible design from many options. It involves defining different design choices as variables, setting a goal to be achieved (like maximizing performance or minimizing cost), and establishing rules that the design must follow. By using mathematical tools, the process identifies the most efficient design that meets all the rules while achieving the goal.

name: automation
short_definition: Automation is the use of technology to make processes happen with less human intervention. This involves using machines that can make decisions and carry out actions, like robots or computer systems.  These technologies help make things more efficient, reduce mistakes, and save time and resources.

name: history of philosophy
short_definition: The history of philosophy is the study of how philosophical ideas have developed over time. It examines how philosophers have argued about fundamental questions like the nature of reality, knowledge, morality, and human existence.  This field looks at both Western and non-Western traditions, highlighting the diverse ways different cultures have approached philosophical inquiry.

name: teacher education
short_definition: Teacher education is the process of preparing individuals to become effective teachers. It involves providing them with the knowledge, skills, and attitudes needed to create engaging learning environments and support student growth. This training helps educators develop into reflective practitioners who can adapt to the diverse needs of students and communities.

name: signal transduction
short_definition: Signal transduction is the process by which cells receive and respond to signals from their environment. This happens through a series of steps, where signals are converted from one form to another, allowing cells to react to changes in their surroundings. These steps are often organized into pathways, like a chain reaction, allowing cells to coordinate their responses and maintain their proper function.

name: music theory
short_definition: Music theory is the study of the building blocks and rules of music. It explores how music is created, organized, and understood, including elements like melody, harmony, rhythm, and form. It analyzes the systems used to create music, like scales, chords, and musical notation.

name: cellular differentiation
short_definition: Cellular differentiation is the process by which unspecialized cells develop into specialized cells with specific functions. This transformation is guided by changes in gene activity, causing cells to adopt different sizes, shapes, and roles. Differentiation is essential for creating a variety of tissues and organs from a single fertilized egg, and it continues throughout life.

name: cognitive impairment
short_definition: Cognitive impairment is a general term for a range of conditions that make it difficult for someone to learn, remember, or think clearly. These difficulties can affect different areas of thinking, such as memory, attention, language, or problem-solving.  Cognitive impairment can be temporary, get worse over time, or stay the same. It can be caused by many things, including illness, injury, or aging.

name: organ transplantation
short_definition: Organ transplantation is a medical procedure where a healthy organ from one person is surgically removed and placed into another person whose organ is failing. This is done to replace a failing organ with a functioning one, giving the recipient a chance at a healthier life. The organ donor is typically someone who has recently passed away and consented to donate their organs, or whose family has made the decision on their behalf.

name: nanotechnology
